comment_text.dn30:1.1.1: The marks of the “five great men” are discussed in the later astrological text, Bṛhatsaṃhitā 69.
comment_text.dn30:1.1.7: This is one of the latest suttas in the Pali Nikāyas. Typically this topic only comes up in relation to the Buddha’s fulfillment of Brahmanical prophecies. Here it is developed with a series of ornate verses, none of which have parallels. Nonetheless, it is worth noting that nowhere in the extensive discussions of the Buddha’s past good deeds is there any mention of the later concepts of the pāramīs (“perfections”) or the Bodhisatta path.
comment_text.dn30:1.2.1: The marks are elsewhere listed in DN 14:1.32.7 and MN 91:9.1. I discuss the translation of the marks in my comments to DN 14.
comment_text.dn30:1.3.5: The later astrological texts such as the Gārgīyajyotiṣa and Bṛhatsaṁhitā that discuss similar marks are more concerned with how they indicate character and destiny than their moral causes.
comment_text.dn30:1.4.1: The key terms here are daḷha (“firm”) and avatthita (“persistently”), which result in his firm stance.
comment_text.dn30:1.5.5: The commentary explain akhilamanimittamakaṇṭakaṁ as “free of bandits” (niccoraṁ). Bandits are also regarded as “pests” (abbuda, literally “tumor” or “cancer”) at SN 1.77:3.4.
comment_text.dn30:1.6.2: K.R. Norman’s series of five articles on The Metres of the Lakkhaṇa-suttanta discusses the verses in detail, and my translation is indebted to him. He notes that the 20 verse passages employ no less than seven distinct metres, all of them either new or updated styles. Such a display of poetic virtuosity is rare in the Pali canon.
comment_text.dn30:1.6.20: The commentary confirms the Mahāsaṅgīti reading khambhana (“obstacle”) here rather than PTS gabbha (‘womb”).
comment_text.dn30:1.7.2: He “conveyed happiness” (sukhāvaho), like a wheeled cart would convey goods. | Parivāra means “surroundings, accompaniments”, and I follow the commentary, which takes it in the sense of the “trimmings” accompanying the food. Given, however, that the kammic result is a large parivāra (“following”), it might mean that he gave not just physical things, but was generous with his followers also, engaging them in such beneficial tasks.
comment_text.dn30:1.9.12: This refers to the late legend of the soothsayers seeing the baby Siddhattha, and as such kumāra should be taken as “prince”.
comment_text.dn30:1.10.5: Giving up killing results in long life. This seems to be applied by metaphor to having these long and elegant body parts.
comment_text.dn30:1.12.9: Whereas in the phrase brahmujugatto, brahm- means “extended, tall”, here brahmāva means “like Brahmā”, either as a play on words or by mistaken etymology.
comment_text.dn30:1.12.14: This verse spoken by the soothsayers.
comment_text.dn30:1.13.2: He receives bodily fullness as a result of giving food.
comment_text.dn30:1.15.5: Nandana, the celestial garden in the realm of the Thirty-Three.
comment_text.dn30:1.16.6: “Tender” because he treated people tenderly; “serried” because his fingers and toes are kept gracefully together, not splayed and separated.
comment_text.dn30:1.17.3: “Inclusive and well-managed” renders saṅgahita. It means “included”, as in those people who, due to the kindly actions, feel that they belong. For the sense “well-managed” see AN 8.49:2.3. Because of acting kindly and inclusively, people are well-disposed and work well together.
comment_text.dn30:1.18.11: Even though the community is geographically dispersed, it is still coherent.
comment_text.dn30:1.19.5: Perhaps the uprightness of these marks relates to his speech being beneficial, leading upwards.
comment_text.dn30:1.22.6: It seems that his “swift” teaching techniques evoke the antelope.
comment_text.dn30:1.25.6: Asking questions leads to wisdom, and the mind of wisdom does not get attached.
comment_text.dn30:1.28.7: Giving fine coverings leads to fine skin. Less obviously, anger is said to lead to discoloring and ugliness.
comment_text.dn30:1.30.2: For this positive sense of adhiṭṭhahi compare AN 6.52:8.2 and MN 140:11.1.
comment_text.dn30:1.30.5: There’s a play on abhivissaji (“gave away”) and abhivassa (“pouring rain”).
comment_text.dn30:1.30.8: Kanaka, one of the many Indic words for gold, is from the same Proto-Indo European root as the English word “honey”.
comment_text.dn30:1.30.14: Here mokkha = pāmokkha (“chief, best”).
comment_text.dn30:1.31.6: The penis is the generative organ and hence part-creator of family. Being covered suggests that his sexuality was moderated and contained. His role was more than having children, it was building family.
comment_text.dn30:2.1.6: The banyan tree is not just proportioned, it offers shelter to many creatures. Touching the knees indicates connecting with the manyfolk, who at AN 5.196:3.1 are likened to caterpillars reaching the knees.
comment_text.dn30:2.4.6: A khema is a sanctuary where animals flourish in peace, without fear of the hunter. Likewise, the Buddha’s body flourishes and has a fullness to it. He is slim but not skinny.
comment_text.dn30:2.5.6: Decline in dhamma is missing here, but present both above and below in verse.
comment_text.dn30:2.8.3: The “ridged taste buds” are not merely for tasting, but support excellent digestion. Kammically, the rationale is that since he did not kill others, now nothing hurts him when he eats.
comment_text.dn30:2.10.5: Dark colored eyes give the impression of wide pupils and an open gaze, while the eyelashes of cows lend them a tenderness.
comment_text.dn30:2.12.10: Abhiyogino (“soothsayers”) is a unique term, explained by the commentary, “they are dedicated to the lore of marks”.
comment_text.dn30:2.13.2: The commentary says he took the lead in good deeds “unembarrassed, with head held high, his head filled with rapture and joy”.
comment_text.dn30:2.16.5: One hair per pore, because his words of truth have only one meaning. Likewise, the tuft conveys purity and integrity.
comment_text.dn30:2.19.5: The number four connotes “all around, complete, universal”, primarily from the four directions. It is multiplied to eight with the intermediate directions, and ten including above and below. Forty, then, is four times ten, a number of super-inclusiveness or super-universality. The lack of gaps corresponds with the lack of division between his followers.
comment_text.dn30:2.25.5: The commentary explains that those who flap their mouths with nonsensical gossip end up with weak or misshapen jaws.
comment_text.dn30:2.28.5: His teeth are not “crooked” or “stained” by corruption.

translation_text.dn30:0.2: The Marks of a Great Man
translation_text.dn30:1.1.2: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
translation_text.dn30:1.1.3: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants,
translation_text.dn30:1.1.7: “There are thirty-two marks of a great man. A great man who possesses these has only two possible destinies, no other.
translation_text.dn30:1.1.8: If he stays at home he becomes a king, a wheel-turning monarch, a just and principled king. His dominion extends to all four sides, he achieves stability in the country, and he possesses the seven treasures.
translation_text.dn30:1.1.9: He has the following seven treasures:
translation_text.dn30:1.1.10: the wheel, the elephant, the horse, the jewel, the woman, the householder, and the commander as the seventh treasure.
translation_text.dn30:1.1.11: He has over a thousand sons who are valiant and heroic, crushing the armies of his enemies.
translation_text.dn30:1.1.12: After conquering this land girt by sea, he reigns by principle, without rod or sword.
translation_text.dn30:1.1.13: But if he goes forth from the lay life to homelessness, he becomes a perfected one, a fully awakened Buddha, who has cast off the world’s veil.
translation_text.dn30:1.2.1: And what are the thirty-two marks?
translation_text.dn30:1.2.5: On the soles of his feet there are thousand-spoked wheels, with rims and hubs, complete in every detail.
translation_text.dn30:1.2.8: His hands and feet are tender.
translation_text.dn30:1.2.9: He has serried hands and feet.
translation_text.dn30:1.2.10: The tops of his feet are arched.
translation_text.dn30:1.2.11: His calves are like those of an antelope.
translation_text.dn30:1.2.12: When standing upright and not bending over, the palms of both hands touch the knees.
translation_text.dn30:1.2.13: His private parts are covered in a foreskin.
translation_text.dn30:1.2.14: He is golden colored; his skin shines like lustrous gold.
translation_text.dn30:1.2.15: He has delicate skin, so delicate that dust and dirt don’t stick to his body.
translation_text.dn30:1.2.16: His hairs grow one per pore.
translation_text.dn30:1.2.17: His hairs stand up; they’re blue-black and curl clockwise.
translation_text.dn30:1.2.18: His body is tall and straight-limbed.
translation_text.dn30:1.2.19: He has bulging muscles in seven places.
translation_text.dn30:1.2.20: His chest is like that of a lion.
translation_text.dn30:1.2.21: He is filled out between the shoulders.
translation_text.dn30:1.2.22: He has the proportional circumference of a banyan tree: the span of his arms equals the height of his body.
translation_text.dn30:1.2.25: His jaw is like that of a lion.
translation_text.dn30:1.2.31: He has the voice of the Divinity, <j>like a cuckoo’s call.
translation_text.dn30:1.2.33: He has eyelashes like a cow’s.
translation_text.dn30:1.2.34: Between his eyebrows there grows a tuft, soft and white like cotton-wool.
translation_text.dn30:1.2.35: The crown of his head is like a turban.
translation_text.dn30:1.3.1: These are the thirty-two marks of a great man. A great man who possesses these has only two possible destinies, no other.
translation_text.dn30:1.3.4: Seers who are outsiders remember these marks, but they do not know
translation_text.dn30:1.3.5: the specific deeds performed in the past to obtain each mark.
translation_text.dn30:1.4.1: In some past lives, past existences, past abodes the Realized One was reborn as a human being. translation_text.dn30:1.4.2: Due to performing, accumulating, heaping up, and amassing those deeds, when his body broke up, after death, he was reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.
translation_text.dn30:1.4.3: There he surpassed the other gods in ten respects: heavenly lifespan, beauty, happiness, glory, sovereignty, sights, sounds, smells, tastes, and touches.

translation_text.dn30:1.5.2: He has the following seven treasures:

translation_text.dn30:1.5.4: He has over a thousand sons who are valiant and heroic, crushing the armies of his enemies.
translation_text.dn30:1.5.5: After conquering this land girt by sea—free of harassment by bandits, successful and prosperous, safe, blessed, free of pests—he reigns by principle, without rod or sword.
translation_text.dn30:1.5.6: And what does he obtain as king?
translation_text.dn30:1.5.7: He can’t be stopped by any human foe or enemy.
translation_text.dn30:1.5.8: That’s what he obtains as king.
translation_text.dn30:1.5.9: But if he goes forth from the lay life to homelessness, he becomes a perfected one, a fully awakened Buddha, who has cast off the world’s veil.
translation_text.dn30:1.5.10: And what does he obtain as Buddha?

translation_text.dn30:2.4.1: “Mendicants, in some past lives the Realized One was reborn as a human being.
translation_text.dn30:2.4.2: He wanted what’s best, the welfare, the comfort, and sanctuary of the people, thinking:
translation_text.dn30:2.4.3: ‘How might they flourish in faith, ethics, learning, generosity, teachings, and wisdom; in wealth and grain, fields and land, birds and beasts, children and partners; in bondservants, workers, and staff; in family, friends, and kin?’
translation_text.dn30:2.4.4: Due to performing those deeds he was reborn in a heavenly realm.
translation_text.dn30:2.4.5: When he came back to this place he obtained these three marks:
translation_text.dn30:2.4.6: his chest is like that of a lion; he is filled out between the shoulders.; and his torso is cylindrical.
translation_text.dn30:2.5.1: Possessing these marks, if he stays at home he becomes a wheel-turning monarch.
translation_text.dn30:2.5.2: And what does he obtain as king?
translation_text.dn30:2.5.3: He’s not liable to decline. He doesn’t decline in wealth and grain, fields and land, birds and beasts, children and partners; in bondservants, workers, and staff; in family, friends, and kin. He doesn’t decline in any of his accomplishments.
translation_text.dn30:2.5.4: That’s what he obtains as king.
translation_text.dn30:2.5.5: And what does he obtain as Buddha?
translation_text.dn30:2.5.6: He’s not liable to decline. He doesn’t decline in faith, ethics, learning, generosity, and wisdom. He doesn’t decline in any of his accomplishments.
translation_text.dn30:2.5.7: That’s what he obtains as Buddha.”

translation_text.dn30:2.6.16: But once gone forth, owning nothing, he attains

translation_text.dn30:2.7.1: “Mendicants, in some past lives the Realized One was reborn as a human being.
translation_text.dn30:2.7.2: He would never hurt any sentient being with fists, stones, rods, or swords.

translation_text.dn30:2.7.4: When he came back to this place he obtained this mark: he has ridged taste buds. His raised taste receptors, originating in the throat, disperse evenly.

translation_text.dn30:2.10.1: “Mendicants, in some past lives the Realized One was reborn as a human being.
translation_text.dn30:2.10.2: When looking at others he didn’t glare, look askance, or avert his eyes. Being straightforward, he reached out to others with straightforward intentions, looking at people with kindly eyes.
translation_text.dn30:2.10.3: Due to performing those deeds he was reborn in a heavenly realm.
translation_text.dn30:2.10.4: When he came back to this place he obtained these two marks:
translation_text.dn30:2.10.5: his eyes are indigo, and he has eyelashes like a cow’s.
translation_text.dn30:2.11.1: Possessing these marks, if he stays at home he becomes a wheel-turning monarch.
translation_text.dn30:2.11.2: And what does he obtain as king?
translation_text.dn30:2.11.3: The people look on him with kindly eyes. He is dear and beloved to the brahmins and householders, people of town and country, finance ministers, military officers, guardsmen, ministers, councillors, rulers, tax beneficiaries, and princes.
translation_text.dn30:2.11.4: That’s what he obtains as king.
translation_text.dn30:2.11.5: And what does he obtain as Buddha?
translation_text.dn30:2.11.6: The people look on him with kindly eyes. He is dear and beloved to the monks, nuns, laymen, laywomen, gods, humans, titans, dragons, and centaurs.
translation_text.dn30:2.11.7: That’s what he obtains as Buddha.”
translation_text.dn30:2.12.2: “With not a glare or glance askance,

translation_text.dn30:2.13.1: “Mendicants, in some past lives the Realized One was reborn as a human being.
translation_text.dn30:2.13.2: He was the leader and forerunner of people in skillful behaviors such as good conduct by way of body, speech, and mind, giving and sharing, taking precepts, observing the sabbath, paying due respect to mother and father, ascetics and brahmins, honoring the elders in the family, and various other things pertaining to skillful behaviors.
translation_text.dn30:2.13.3: Due to performing those deeds he was reborn in a heavenly realm.
translation_text.dn30:2.13.4: When he came back to this place he obtained this mark:
translation_text.dn30:2.13.5: the crown of his head is like a turban.
translation_text.dn30:2.14.1: Possessing this mark, if he stays at home he becomes a wheel-turning monarch.
translation_text.dn30:2.14.2: And what does he obtain as king?
translation_text.dn30:2.14.3: He has a large following of brahmins and householders, people of town and country, finance ministers, military officers, guardsmen, ministers, councillors, rulers, tax beneficiaries, and princes.
translation_text.dn30:2.14.4: That’s what he obtains as king.
translation_text.dn30:2.14.5: And what does he obtain as Buddha?
translation_text.dn30:2.14.6: He has a large following of monks, nuns, laymen, laywomen, gods, humans, titans, dragons, and centaurs.
translation_text.dn30:2.14.7: That’s what he obtains as Buddha.”

translation_text.dn30:2.16.0: 24–25. One Hair Per Pore, and a Tuft
translation_text.dn30:2.16.1: “Mendicants, in some past lives the Realized One was reborn as a human being.
translation_text.dn30:2.16.2: He refrained from lying. He spoke the truth and stuck to the truth. He was honest and dependable, and didn’t trick the world with his words.
translation_text.dn30:2.16.3: Due to performing those deeds he was reborn in a heavenly realm.
translation_text.dn30:2.16.4: When he came back to this place he obtained these two marks:
translation_text.dn30:2.16.5: his hairs grow one per pore, and between his eyebrows there grows a tuft, soft and white like cotton-wool.
translation_text.dn30:2.17.1: Possessing these marks, if he stays at home he becomes a wheel-turning monarch.
translation_text.dn30:2.17.2: And what does he obtain as king?
translation_text.dn30:2.17.3: He has many close adherents among the brahmins and householders, people of town and country, finance ministers, military officers, guardsmen, ministers, councillors, rulers, tax beneficiaries, and princes.
translation_text.dn30:2.17.4: That’s what he obtains as king.
translation_text.dn30:2.17.5: And what does he obtain as Buddha?
translation_text.dn30:2.17.6: He has many close adherents among the monks, nuns, laymen, laywomen, gods, humans, titans, dragons, and centaurs.
translation_text.dn30:2.17.7: That’s what he obtains as Buddha.”

translation_text.dn30:2.18.16: But once gone forth, owning nothing,

translation_text.dn30:2.19.1: “Mendicants, in some past lives the Realized One was reborn as a human being.
translation_text.dn30:2.19.2: He refrained from divisive speech. He didn’t repeat in one place what he heard in another so as to divide people against each other. Instead, he reconciled those who were divided and support those who are united, delighting in harmony, loving harmony, speaking words that promote harmony.
translation_text.dn30:2.19.3: Due to performing those deeds he was reborn in a heavenly realm.
translation_text.dn30:2.19.4: When he came back to this place he obtained these two marks:
translation_text.dn30:2.19.5: he has forty teeth, and his teeth have no gaps.
translation_text.dn30:2.20.1: Possessing these marks, if he stays at home he becomes a wheel-turning monarch.
translation_text.dn30:2.20.2: And what does he obtain as king?
translation_text.dn30:2.20.3: His retinue cannot be divided. This includes brahmins and householders, people of town and country, finance ministers, military officers, guardsmen, ministers, councillors, rulers, tax beneficiaries, and princes.
translation_text.dn30:2.20.4: That’s what he obtains as king.
translation_text.dn30:2.20.5: And what does he obtain as Buddha?
translation_text.dn30:2.20.6: His retinue cannot be divided. This includes monks, nuns, laymen, laywomen, gods, humans, titans, dragons, and centaurs.
translation_text.dn30:2.20.7: That’s what he obtains as Buddha.”

translation_text.dn30:2.22.0: 28–29. A Large Tongue and the Voice of the Divinity
translation_text.dn30:2.22.1: “Mendicants, in some past lives the Realized One was reborn as a human being.
translation_text.dn30:2.22.2: He refrained from harsh speech. He spoke in a way that’s mellow, pleasing to the ear, lovely, going to the heart, polite, likable and agreeable to the people.
translation_text.dn30:2.22.3: Due to performing those deeds he was reborn in a heavenly realm.
translation_text.dn30:2.22.4: When he came back to this place he obtained these two marks:
translation_text.dn30:2.22.5: he has a large tongue, and the voice of the Divinity, like a cuckoo’s call.
translation_text.dn30:2.23.1: Possessing these marks, if he stays at home he becomes a wheel-turning monarch.
translation_text.dn30:2.23.2: And what does he obtain as king?

translation_text.dn30:2.23.4: That’s what he obtains as king.
translation_text.dn30:2.23.5: And what does he obtain as Buddha?
translation_text.dn30:2.23.6: He has a compelling voice. His words are compelling to monks, nuns, laymen, laywomen, gods, humans, titans, dragons, and centaurs.
translation_text.dn30:2.23.7: That’s what he obtains as Buddha.”

translation_text.dn30:2.25.1: “Mendicants, in some past lives the Realized One was reborn as a human being.
translation_text.dn30:2.25.2: He refrained from talking nonsense. His words were timely, true, and meaningful, in line with the teaching and training. He said things at the right time which were valuable, reasonable, succinct, and beneficial.
translation_text.dn30:2.25.3: Due to performing those deeds he was reborn in a heavenly realm.
translation_text.dn30:2.25.4: When he came back to this place he obtained this mark:
translation_text.dn30:2.25.5: his jaw is like that of a lion.
translation_text.dn30:2.26.1: Possessing this mark, if he stays at home he becomes a wheel-turning monarch.
translation_text.dn30:2.26.2: And what does he obtain as king?
translation_text.dn30:2.26.3: He can’t be destroyed by any human foe or enemy.
translation_text.dn30:2.26.4: That’s what he obtains as king.
translation_text.dn30:2.26.5: And what does he obtain as Buddha?
translation_text.dn30:2.26.6: He can’t be destroyed by any foe or enemy whether internal or external; nor by greed, hate, or delusion; nor by any ascetic or brahmin or god or Māra or divinity or by anyone in the world.

translation_text.dn30:2.28.1: “Mendicants, in some past lives the Realized One was reborn as a human being.
translation_text.dn30:2.28.2: He gave up wrong livelihood and earned a living by right livelihood. He refrained from falsifying weights, metals, or measures; bribery, fraud, cheating, and duplicity; mutilation, murder, abduction, banditry, plunder, and violence.
translation_text.dn30:2.28.3: Due to performing, accumulating, heaping up, and amassing those deeds, when his body broke up, after death, he was reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.
translation_text.dn30:2.28.4: There he surpassed the other gods in ten respects: heavenly lifespan, beauty, happiness, glory, sovereignty, sights, sounds, smells, tastes, and touches.
translation_text.dn30:2.28.5: When he came back to this place he obtained these two marks: his teeth are even and perfectly white.

translation_text.dn30:2.29.3: the wheel, the elephant, the horse, the jewel, the woman, the householder, and the commander as the seventh treasure.
translation_text.dn30:2.29.4: He has over a thousand sons who are valiant and heroic, crushing the armies of his enemies.
translation_text.dn30:2.29.5: After conquering this land girt by sea—free of harassment by bandits, successful and prosperous, safe, blessed, and free of pests—he reigns by principle, without rod or sword.
translation_text.dn30:2.29.6: And what does he obtain as king?
translation_text.dn30:2.29.7: His retinue is pure. This includes brahmins and householders, people of town and country, finance ministers, military officers, guardsmen, ministers, councillors, rulers, tax beneficiaries, and princes.
translation_text.dn30:2.29.8: That’s what he obtains as king.
translation_text.dn30:2.30.1: But if he goes forth from the lay life to homelessness, he becomes a perfected one, a fully awakened Buddha, who has cast off the world’s veil.
translation_text.dn30:2.30.2: And what does he obtain as Buddha?

translation_text.dn30:2.30.4: That’s what he obtains as Buddha.”
